title: My Danish Sweetheart: A Novel. Volume 3 of 3

quoteFirst: Supposing your hours free, the best are those in which the daylight is most powerful: say, from ten in the morning until four in the afternoon; or, to take things in moderation, from
quoteLast: . A beaching expedition made thus with determinate purpose, once or twice in the course of six days, I hold to be reasonable diversion; and for matter of interest, I know of no out-door pursuit which excels it, not even Insect-catching, or Fly-fishing.
title:
Beach Rambles in Search of Seaside Pebbles and Crystals
With Some Observations on the Origin of the Diamond and Other Precious Stones
author: Francis, John George

quoteFirst: During the first watch, from seven to eleven, Dick was to be in charge of the motor and Carl was to take the lookout, while Matt slept; from
quoteLast: , Matt was to look after the motor, Carl was to continue on lookout duty, and Dick was to sleep; and from three to seven, Carl was to sleep and Dick was to relieve him.
title:
Motor Matt's Peril; or, Cast Away in the Bahamas
Motor Stories Thrilling Adventure Motor Fiction No. 12, May 15, 1909
author: Matthews, Stanley R.

quoteFirst: From six to nine in the morning the forests resound with the mingled cries and strains of the feathered race; after this they gradually die away.  From
quoteLast: all nature is hushed as in a midnight silence, and scarce a note is heard, saving that of the campanero and the pi-pi-yo; it is then that, oppressed by the solar heat, the birds retire to the thickest shade and wait for the refreshing cool of evening.
title: Wanderings in South America
author: Waterton, Charles, 1782-1865; Moore, Norman, 1847-1922 [Author of introduction, etc.]

The man among the monkeys; or, Ninety days in apeland

title: The Ghost Ship
